video_caption: The video begins with a title slide displaying "FWHM using ORIGIN" in bold red letters, accompanied by a graph labeled "XRD Pattern" showing a series of peaks with annotations such as "α-Fe2O3" and "550°C / 48 hrs." A diagram on the right illustrates the Full Width at Half Maximum (FWHM) with labeled parameters "xc = 0," "w = 4," and "A = 10." The scene transitions to a computer screen showing the ORIGIN software interface, with a spreadsheet on the left and a blank graph area on the right. The spreadsheet contains columns labeled "Long Name," "A0," "B0," and "Comments," with numerical data in the "A0" column. The next frame presents a slide titled "Crystallite Size Broadening," featuring a formula "B(2θ) = Kλ / L cos θ" and bullet points explaining the relationship between peak width, crystallite size, and 2θ angle. The video then shows a close-up of the same slide, with a cursor pointing to the formula, emphasizing the educational content. The final frame returns to the ORIGIN software interface, now with a graph displaying a single peak labeled "Average=0.0 Count=4-AU ON," indicating the software's capability to analyze and visualize XRD data. Throughout the video, the focus remains on the educational and analytical aspects of XRD pattern analysis using ORIGIN software.

The video features a presentation slide titled "Crystallite Size Broadening," which explains the relationship between crystallite size and peak width in X-ray diffraction analysis. The slide includes a mathematical formula, B(2θ) = Kλ / L cos θ, where B(2θ) represents the peak width, K is a constant, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray, L is the crystallite size, and θ is the diffraction angle. The slide also contains bullet points detailing how peak width varies with crystallite size, the effect of angle on peak width, and the optimal range for using a single diffraction peak for analysis. The background is white, and the text is in black, with the title in bold. The slide remains static throughout the video, with no visible changes or movements.

The video presents a slide titled "Crystallite Size Broadening," which is part of a scientific or educational presentation. The slide features a mathematical formula, B(2θ) = Kλ / L cos θ, at the top, indicating a relationship between peak width and crystal size. Below the formula, there are bullet points explaining the concept of peak width due to crystallite size, its variation with 2θ as cos θ, and the implications of crystallite size broadening at large angles 2θ. The slide also discusses the instrumental profile width and microstrain broadening, as well as the peak intensity and its relationship with larger angles 2θ. Additionally, it mentions the optimal range for using a single diffraction peak for better results and the compromise of peak asymmetry in profile analysis. The background is plain white, and the text is in black, making it easy to read. Throughout the video, the slide remains static with no changes in the content or layout, and there are no people or other objects visible. The focus is solely on the educational content presented on the slide.

The video begins with a slide titled "Crystallite Size Broadening," which explains the relationship between peak width and crystallite size in X-ray diffraction analysis. The slide includes a formula, B(2θ) = Kλ / L cos θ, and bullet points detailing how peak width varies with crystallite size and angle 2θ. The background is white, and the text is in black, with some words highlighted in blue. The scene then transitions to a computer screen displaying an open Microsoft Excel spreadsheet titled "Book1." The spreadsheet has columns labeled "A00," "A01," and "A02," with rows numbered from 1 to 25. The cursor is visible on the screen, indicating user interaction. The video continues to show the Excel spreadsheet, with the cursor moving to different cells, suggesting data entry or manipulation. The environment remains consistent, with the focus on the spreadsheet and the user's interaction with it. The video concludes with the cursor still visible on the spreadsheet, indicating ongoing activity.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet titled "Book1" with columns labeled "Long Name," "A(X)," and "B(Y)." The spreadsheet contains numerical data in rows, with the first row showing "10" in column A and "22.5" in column B. The Excel interface is visible, including the ribbon with various tabs and tools. The user interacts with the spreadsheet, opening a Notepad window titled "alphafile203_900.raw" that contains text and numerical data. The Notepad window is then minimized, and the focus returns to the Excel spreadsheet, where the user highlights specific cells in blue, indicating selection or editing. The video concludes with the Excel spreadsheet still open, displaying the highlighted cells and the numerical data in the background.

The video showcases a user interacting with OriginPro 9.6 software, a data analysis and graphing tool. Initially, the user navigates through the software's menu, specifically focusing on the 'Plot' option, which reveals a dropdown menu with various plotting options such as 'Line,' 'Symbol,' 'Column/Bar/Pe,' and more. The user then proceeds to open a data table named 'Book1,' displaying two columns labeled 'A(X)' and 'B(Y)' with numerical data. Subsequently, the user generates a graph from this data, which plots 'Intensity' on the y-axis against '2θ' on the x-axis, resulting in a purple line graph with multiple peaks. The graph is labeled 'B' in the legend, indicating it represents the data from column 'B(Y).' The video concludes with a zoomed-in view of the graph, highlighting specific peaks and their corresponding intensity values, providing a detailed analysis of the data. Throughout the video, the user's actions are focused on data visualization and analysis within the OriginPro software environment.

The video showcases a detailed process of analyzing a graph using OriginLab software. Initially, a graph with a purple line labeled 'B' is displayed, featuring a peak around the 32 mark on the x-axis and a y-axis labeled 'Intensity' ranging from 0 to 600. The user interacts with the graph, zooming in on the peak and using the 'Get Peaks' tool to identify and adjust the peak's center. The software then fits a Gaussian function to the data, displaying parameters such as 'xc' (center), 'A' (amplitude), and 'w' (FWHM). The fit is refined, and the results are shown in a detailed table, including the 'Reduced Chi-Sqr' value and 'Fit Status'. The video concludes with a summary of the fit, highlighting the success of the analysis and the detailed parameters obtained from the Gaussian fit. Throughout the video, the user interface of OriginLab is visible, with various tools and options for data analysis and graph manipulation.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying a graph with a prominent peak, labeled as "B" in blue and "Gaussian Fit of Sheet1 B" in red, indicating a Gaussian fit applied to the data. The graph is plotted against the x-axis labeled "2θ" and the y-axis labeled "Intensity." To the right of the graph, a detailed table presents the Gaussian model's equation, reduced chi-square value, adjusted R-square value, and the values and standard errors for parameters y0, xc, A, and w. The table's values are consistent across the frames, with y0 at 15.8778, xc at 33.23319, A at 90.18639, and w at 0.19842. The video transitions through different views of the graph and table, including a zoomed-in view of the peak, a full-screen view of the graph, and a view of the graph within a presentation slide. The interface elements, such as menu options and toolbars, are visible throughout, indicating the use of a data analysis or presentation software. The environment suggests a focus on data analysis, with the graph and table providing insights into the characteristics of the data being analyzed.

The video showcases a series of frames from a computer screen displaying a data analysis software interface, likely used for scientific or engineering purposes. Initially, the interface shows a graph with two lines, one labeled 'B' and the other 'Gaussian Fit of Sheet1!E,' indicating a comparison between raw data and a Gaussian fit. The graph is accompanied by a table with columns labeled 'Model,' 'Equation,' and 'Reduced Chi-Sqr,' suggesting statistical analysis. The user navigates through the software, opening a 'Log' window and selecting various options from a dropdown menu, including 'Delete' and 'Set Column Values.' The focus then shifts to a new graph with a purple line representing 'Intensity' on the y-axis and a numerical range on the x-axis, displaying multiple peaks. A 'Reminder Message' dialog box appears, reminding the user about customizing graphs and saving templates. The user proceeds to select 'Multiple Peak Fit' from the 'Analysis' menu, leading to a 'Spectroscopy nfitpeaks' dialog box where the user inputs parameters for fitting peaks with a Gaussian function. The user then selects 'Get Points' from a dropdown menu, indicating the selection of specific data points for analysis. The video concludes with the user selecting 'Open NLFit,' likely to open a new window for non-linear fitting, with the graph still displaying the purple line and the selected peaks highlighted. Throughout the video, the user interacts with the software, navigating through menus and dialog boxes to perform data analysis tasks, with the interface elements and graphs providing a visual representation of the data and analysis process.

The video showcases a series of frames from a computer screen displaying a spectroscopy software interface. Initially, the screen shows a graph with a purple line representing a spectrum, featuring two prominent peaks labeled '1' and '2'. A dialog box titled 'Fit Peak (Gaussian)' is open, detailing parameters such as 'A', 'w', 'A_2', 'w_2', and 'center', with corresponding values and checkboxes for 'Significant Digits'. The user interacts with the software, adjusting settings and attempting to fit the peaks with a Gaussian function. The interface includes various tabs and options like 'Result', 'Formula', 'Sample Curve', and 'Messages', with a 'Done' button highlighted. The user then closes the dialog box, and the graph remains visible with the peaks labeled '1' and '2'. Subsequently, a new dialog box titled 'Spectroscopy rfitpeaks' appears, offering options to pick multiple peaks and fit them with a Gaussian function. The user selects two peaks, and the software displays a message indicating the selection of two peaks with their respective coordinates. The video concludes with the user interacting with the graph, highlighting the peaks and adjusting the fit, with the software providing feedback on the selected peaks and their coordinates. Throughout the video, the environment remains consistent, focusing on the software interface and the graph, with no visible people or additional background details.

The video showcases a series of frames from a computer screen displaying a graph and a dialog box for fitting a Gaussian curve to the data. The graph plots intensity against an unspecified variable, with two prominent peaks labeled "B Peak 1" and "B Peak 2." The dialog box titled "Dialog Fit (Gaussian)" contains various parameters and settings for the curve fitting process, including "Settings," "Theme," "Parameters," and "Bounds." The user interacts with the dialog box, adjusting settings and observing the changes in the graph. The graph updates to show the fit peaks and the cumulative fit peak, with the dialog box displaying the equation and statistical values for the fit. The video concludes with the graph and dialog box remaining on the screen, showing the final fit results. The environment is a typical computer interface with a focus on data analysis and curve fitting.

The video begins with a graph displaying a blue line labeled 'B' and two peaks labeled 'Fit Peak 1' and 'Fit Peak 2,' along with a cumulative fit line. The graph is accompanied by a table on the right side, detailing the Gaussian model equation and various statistical values such as reduced chi-squared, adjusted R-squared, and peak parameters. The scene then transitions to a colorful end screen featuring a laptop with a landscape image on its screen, set against a patterned background. The words "More Videos" are written above the laptop, with an arrow pointing towards it, and social media icons for Facebook, Twitter, and Google+ are displayed on the right side. Below the laptop, there is a red "subscribe" button, encouraging viewers to subscribe to the channel. The video maintains this end screen throughout the remainder of the frames, emphasizing the call to action for viewers to explore more content and subscribe.
